@nphetaredone Fares have been reduced across the entire country, the Dublin fares were the last to be implemented, with urban and rural bus and train fares reduced by 20% last month.

We're also extending the 20% average fare reduction currently available online for @IrishRail tickets to in-person ticket machines, completing the 20% reduction in public transport across the State.  We have delivered the first reduction in Public Transport fares since 1947. https://t.co/ahrFWJOWm3

@CunneenKeith @DubCityCouncil Thankfully, more pedestrian space increases footfall, ultimately benefiting commerce.  Additionally deliveries by vehicle will still be permitted between the hours 6am and 11am, just like Henry and Grafton Streets, where commerce continues to thrive.
You can read more here: https://t.co/JFAuJ3KEBk

If you still remain concerned about impacts that may arise as a result of this new layout, you can continue to engage with the City Council.  The council will be reviewing and monitoring the new layout between now and September when a report will be presented to Councillors

The consultation held to explore this proposal was the largest ever held by Dublin City Council and shows once again the good that can be achieved when citizens engage with local and national government.  Well done again, and enjoy your new pedestrian space!

Councillors; including my @greenparty_ie colleague @JanetPHorner, who has championed this proposal from the early stages, this morning voted to enact the proposal  In just 3-4 weeks the vibrant, eclectic and unique street will be traffic free, save for deliveries between 6am-11am https://t.co/nvN2WzDWzZ

Aware that the preview says "Page not found", that's a an issue with Twitter's previewing mechanism.  If you click the link it does open to the correct page.

We will focus on the people who will be affected most by the regulations - in particular low income households who rely on turf as a cheap but inefficient form of fuel with targeted retrofitting and ongoing social welfare supports.
Under the regulations, households in small villages and one-off houses would still be allowed to burn turf, or gift or sell a few bags to neighbours.    Misinformation otherwise is scaremongering.
The main aim of the draft Solid Fuel Regulations is to end the large scale and commercial sale of smoky fuels into urban areas, not the traditional burning of turf in rural areas.

Can we wait to let another 1,300 people die or wait for the next trolley crisis before we tackle the large scale sale of smoky fuels?   The draft smoky fuel regulations have always been about getting the balance right between tackling fuel poverty and protecting people‚Äôs health. https://t.co/KEh8zZNuCA
